title: Score Amnesia Plague
story_summary: In the tightly managed city of Stenograd, where every citizen's life is governed by the all-seeing Behavioral Compliance Index, disillusioned administrator Daria Tomenko makes a daring choice: haunted by her brother's fate, she triggers a data erasure that wipes thousands of BCI profiles overnight. Suddenly invisible to the system, these citizens lose access to jobs and homes, chaos rippling through the city. But from confusion, resilience grows - those erased forge new 'amnesiac' communities grounded in trust, while black markets for fake identities thrive beneath the Council's watchful gaze. Attempts to restore order only fuel solidarity and underground defiance; soon, even compliant citizens quietly support the outcasts. With old controls breaking and spontaneous mutual aid blossoming across Stenograd, the Council's iron grip weakens, and a spirit of open resistance kindles citywide, promising new life beyond the algorithms.

official.headline: Minor System Outage
official.anchor_line: A technical update led to temporary glitches in the Behavioral Compliance Index, or BCI, impacting some digital profiles citywide.
official.contextual_reframing: The Council assures continued service optimization. Stenograd's automated governance adapts efficiently to system feedback.

official.headline: Community Support Rises
official.anchor_line: Citizens affected by the BCI update are supported by local networks and high-score volunteers.
official.contextual_reframing: This demonstrates the resilience of our rational social infrastructure, where trusted community cooperation complements official systems.

official.headline: Services Remain Accessible
official.anchor_line: Essential public services and kiosks continue to operate smoothly despite digital irregularities.
official.contextual_reframing: Stenograd's infrastructure safeguards reliability, blending biometric and manual verification for all.

underground.headline: Thousands Vanish Overnight
underground.anchor_line: Woke up profile-less? Welcome to the BCI blackout - where your digital life gets erased with no warning.
underground.contextual_reframing: The Behavioral Compliance Index, or BCI, runs your world - from housing to food. Now thousands are locked out, stranded by the system they were told would protect them.

underground.headline: Black Markets Boom
underground.anchor_line: Missing your BCI score? New markets for fake profiles, forged testimonials, and communal access pop up everywhere.
underground.contextual_reframing: Citizens are beating the Council at their own game. When trust is measured by code, people turn to each other - and to creative workarounds.

underground.headline: Trust Beats Tech
underground.anchor_line: Amnesiac communities rise, surviving outside the Council's control. People help people - no score required.
underground.contextual_reframing: The cracks in automated rule are showing. Stenograd's system claims to predict and control behavior, but nothing outsmarts old-fashioned solidarity.

hobby.message: Urban exploration or just drinking underground?
That camera still your favorite weapon?
Origami helping you dodge the spiral?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Colder? Maybe. Hard to say these days.
Not many folks out after dark anymore.
I spend time in old tunnels, city's insides.
Things feel different underground since those records vanished.
Definitely quieter. Streets lost their rhythm.
I stick to my routine - urban exploring, utility shafts and old nodes.
Helps having a map when systems glitch out.
Last week's blackout made some routes easier to move through.
Nothing stays the same down there.
Colder, sure. Not just the weather - the silence, too.
I roam the old maintenance tunnels for fun. Urban exploring, if you like.
Been at it for years, tracking changes nobody upstairs sees.
Since the BCI wipe, most sensors down there are dead or erratic.
Ran into a couple others last night, all just making do.
Strange how it feels almost friendly underground now.
Feels like the machine's asleep - colder, but free in some places.
Exploring sealed tunnels and abandoned data centers is my thing.
I've mapped more of the city's guts than I ever planned.
That BCI erasure? Less surveillance, so more folks poking around.
Last time out we even shared a drink and some stories - used to be unthinkable.
You'd be surprised how much trust pops up when you're off the grid.
Old utility blueprints are worth more than credits right now.
Yeah, the city's cold, but it's alive underneath. Lost a lot of watchers lately.
Urban exploring's my escape - slipping through tunnels, cracking dead panels, old data rooms.
Used to need a high score just to avoid getting flagged for trespass.
Since the BCI profiles vanished, it's wilder down there. Less predictable. More human, in a way.
Found communities trading favors, maps, even old paper manuals last Sunday underground.
Got into a locked substation by using a trick I picked up fixing water mains for neighbors.
Ran the loop for six hours - longest stretch in years. Didn't worry who was tracking me.
Funny, trust felt like currency again. Whole city's rewiring itself from the shadows.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still poking around down there. Keeps the mind busy.
Tunnels are quieter since the wipe. Fewer patrols.
People keep to themselves now. Fine by me.
No profiles checking up, just shadows.
The new quiet makes a difference.
You guessed it. Still exploring, when I can.
Less hassle, fewer cameras after all that BCI erasure.
Tunnels feel emptier, but you notice eyes linger longer now.
People trade food, not favors.
Funny how folks vanish when no one's keeping lists.
Doesn't mean it's safer, mind you.
Right as ever. Urban exploring with a flask - best way to ride the grid failures.
Whole undercity's changed since the records vanished - doors open, sensors blind half the time.
Used to worry about trespass alerts. Now I look out for people, not the system.
Ran into a few like me, all running low or trading skills.
Bartering's back - help with a valve, swap for a meal.
Had a full conversation last week, just over a busted breaker.
Makes it less lonely, I suppose.
Spot on, Alex. Homebrew makes the concrete friendlier - and people talkative.
Used to sneak around, counting every camera. Now? System's as lost as the rest of us.
BCI vanishing made tunnels popular. Ran into other ghosted folks more than sensors lately.
Heard a dozen stories about profiles gone - people rebuilding trust, face to face.
One guy traded me old maps for technical advice. Never got his real name - didn't matter.
Bartering's honest when no one's watching. Actually fixed someone's water tap for bread.
I keep hand notes now - digital means nothing without a profile.
Urban exploring's a different kind of risky these days.
Still at it, Alex. Found my first relay duct at sixteen, never grew out of it.
Urban exploring's never been about secrets - just figuring out what the city forgets.
These last couple weeks changed everything. No BCI, no digital leash - humans instead of profiles.
Tunnels went from lonely to lively - ran into three crews in a night, all profile ghosts.
Homebrew shares better in the dark. Brought folks together who barely spoke above ground.
Funny, system tried to scare us out - ended up building new trust off-grid.
Been keeping paper logs, trading routes for stories now.
I fix old pumps, rewire dead panels - just to keep things moving local.
Feels like the city's remembering itself, one unscored favor at a time.

main.opener: Funny how things shift without anyone saying much. You seen that around you?
variants: Yeah, I've noticed things aren't running how they used to. People queuing up instead of breezing through.
Had to do a job for someone without the usual clearance. Just handshakes, no checks.
Been keeping my head down. Taking work when I find it.
Feels like the ground's gone soft underfoot. Can't say it's comfortable.
Things feel odd out there. Folks stuck outside the centers with no idea what they're waiting for.
I had someone come to me about a water pump no one's supposed to use. Normally I'd say no.
Ended up taking the job, mostly for supplies. No oversight to worry about, but everyone's on edge.
Did my notes the old way. Paper's safer now than the system.
All this makes you wonder who's really in charge. It's unsettling.
You could say I've seen some shifts lately. All those wiped BCI profiles - they don't just grow back overnight.
Saw people trading favors, not credits. Like the rules changed and no one got the memo.
Fixed an unlicensed pump for someone I've known years. Trust's the new currency, I guess.
No official approval, just word-of-mouth. Felt risky but honest.
I didn't log it with the city - just wrote it down by hand.
Hard to shake the feeling that nothing's certain now, except your neighbors.
Oh, I've seen it firsthand. Yesterday morning I was stuck outside a distribution center. Everyone was - no BCI, no entry.
Normally, getting supplies is all automatic, system says yes or no. Now it's more about who knows you.
Had an old client ask for help fixing a pump the city would shut down in a heartbeat. No permits, no paperwork.
I took the job - swapped my work for groceries. Haven't done that since I was a rookie.
Way things went, felt more real than any system-logged contract.
I didn't touch the public records, just scribbled it in a notebook.
It's strange - without the system, people just... start trusting each other again. Makes you wonder what's actually holding us together.
Funny you ask. You know I used to keep everything legit - systems work, digital logs, all that. Not lately.
I spent the morning with half the city standing outside the depot, everyone locked out. No scores, no profiles.
The rules are gone. People who never talked to each other suddenly share tools or band together for supplies.
One woman - someone I did work for before - asked for help with her blacklisted pump. If anyone from the Directorate saw it, we'd both be flagged.
I took the risk. She gave me food in return. I haven't bartered like that since before the BCI got teeth.
Didn't even think to run it through the queue. Just marked it in my own journal.
The official system? Not even pretending to hold things together now. Only thing that works is trust, tribe, and what you can fix yourself.
Honestly, for all the Innovators' talk, it's the small defiant choices that are changing things - and for once, I think that might be alright.
main.emotion: Feels like I'm walking a tightrope - off balance, but wide awake for the first time in years.

emotional.opener: Lenart, you haven't lost your balance - you've just stopped pretending the line was ever straight. That's clarity, not failure.
variants: Suppose you're right. Maybe seeing it for what it is isn't the problem.
Guess I'm better off awake than sleepwalking.
Could be there's something to what you said. Wide awake is risky, but at least it's real.
Funny how pretending gets heavier than just facing it.
Reckon I can live with clarity. For now.
I keep telling myself, balance is overrated. Maybe it's the wobble that keeps you from falling asleep up there.
Feels strange, but I kind of like knowing where I stand - even if it's unsteady.
Clarity's refreshing, even when it stings.
Appreciate you seeing that. Doesn't happen much.
You know, it's odd. Most days I'd have traded anything for solid ground, but at least now I know there's nothing down there to miss.
Wide awake feels sharp, but honest. Less room for regret than I expected.
Pretending the line was straight was half the problem.
Feels good, in a warped way, that someone notices the difference.
Suppose 'clarity' isn't the worst label I've had.
Used to think the whole point was to pass for normal, keep your head down - keep the system happy.
But I haven't felt this alert in years. Maybe alert's better than safe.
Pretending everything lined up just made it worse, like standing on ice you know will crack.
Kind of funny, I never thought anyone else saw that tension - the fear behind the balance.
Feels lighter now. Not easier, but lighter.
Thanks for getting it. Most people think waking up is the mistake.

factual.opener: Come on, Lenart. Everyone knows more's going on. Just tell me what's really happening out there.
variants: People are nervous. The city's off-balance.
Some say folks who vanished are popping back up.
Council's clashing, not handling things well.
Whole place feels less safe than it did last month.
There's chatter about profiles being wiped. Makes people unpredictable.
Heard of black markets popping up. Fake profiles, quick deals.
Some high-scorers seem rattled, laying low.
Council's pointing fingers but not solving much.
Feels like the city's running on guesswork, not rules.
Black markets aren't rumors now. Bought a forged profile just to test it.
Saw 'amnesiac' communities come together. They're running better than most districts.
Even some trusted citizens are helping out, quietly.
Labor assignments are a mess - engineers cleaning streets, drivers handling power grids.
I hear protests are spreading fast. The Council's grip is slipping.
Innovators always talked about adaptability. This is probably what they meant, even if it's sideways.
You can see the cracks forming if you know where to look.
The so-called erased are running things on the ground. Makes you wonder if the BCI ever did much.
Had to swap favors with one of their networks last night. System can't track half of it.
Saw protestors share Council history leaks. People are holding their own trials, not waiting for the system.
Heard a Directorate man lost his post, outed by one of those old simulation files.
I trust the Innovators' angle - letting things evolve, not strangling them.
Supply pools are local now. If you pull strings, you get what you need.
Anyone holding to the old rules is getting sidelined, fast.
Feels like everything that's broken is forcing people to invent new ways to get by.
I know half the city's working off ledgers or borrowed IDs now. The old BCI gates are just for show.
I loaned my tools to a group who used to be 'invisibles.' They decoded a Council leak to spring more folks.
The puzzle app's not a game - more like a roadmap for putting BCI ghosts back in play.
Ex-engineers like me are in demand. I've fixed three labor placement terminals this week, all for barter.
Supply runs are crowdsourced. One group pooled resources, wired up their own micro-grid.
Some Innovators saw this coming - BCI's collapse forced the network to go human and local again. Honestly, that appeals to me.
Saw a Council member slink out a back alley - guess the algorithms never planned for panic.
Heard the Directorate's snatching up anyone selling fake profiles, but they can't keep up.
Trust, skills, and a little risk - feels more alive than any data-driven order ever did.

hobby.message: Origami helping you dodge the spiral?
Typewriters treating you better than people?
You still hunting political literature no one's supposed to find?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: City's kind enough, if one avoids trouble.
I collect old books, mostly political ones. Nothing popular.
That got harder after the last erasures.
Some things stay hidden for a reason.
Kind is relative these days.
I still collect banned political works, despite the risks.
Saw fewer opportunities after the system went wild.
Erased records make sources unpredictable.
Safer to stay cautious.
Kindness is about what you can keep.
My hobby's collecting banned political texts - restoring them, sometimes memorizing passages.
Lost a reliable contact in the last BCI wipe.
Had to rely on luck for my last trade.
Texts are harder to verify now.
At least the thrill hasn't changed.
Depends who's asking. The city disrupts as easily as it rewards.
I collect and restore prohibited literature - years tracking down first editions, pamphlets, the rare manifestos.
The erasures broke my usual channels - books came out of hiding, but trust is scarce.
Last week I bartered for a volume in a crowd - familiar faces, old rivals, all unrecorded now.
Read aloud by candlelight. Off registry, off record.
It's private work, sometimes public risk.
Keeps the mind sharp.
The city's gracious to those who fit its narrative. The rest improvise.
I've spent half my life collecting forbidden political tracts - annotating, restoring, learning to recite from memory.
After the profile wipe, my cohorts showed up openly with bundles - no need to whisper for once.
Our safest courier is now a bookbinder with no BCI at all.
Last weekend, a Council loyalist quoted an old regime speech over vodka, no fear of listeners.
We exchanged texts in daylight - ridiculous, exhilarating.
I keep an archive, handwritten notes from before my score slid this low.
Most think these are just stories. For me, it's a ledger of history, survival.
hobby_answer: Same books, yes. Only reading now, nothing more.
Harder to find originals since the last purge.
Most people trade fakes or summaries, nothing reliable.
Curfews make travel... cumbersome. Too many eyes, everywhere.
Lately, it's safer to remember than to collect.
Still at it, but the city's different after the erasures.
Good editions are scarcer, black market flooded with forgeries.
Last week's network blackout froze a few reliable suppliers.
I stick to trusted texts, the old Council manifestos mostly.
Not wise to keep much at home since patrols ignore usual protocols.
People are bolder now, but that's not always an advantage.
Same banned books. Collecting became strange business since the score wipe.
A lot of forgeries out there - some clever, some laughable.
Recent amnesiac groups swap pamphlets openly, less fear than before.
Erasures emptied old caches, so circulation is unpredictable.
I traded for an original last Friday - first time in public in years.
Council pamphlets, dissident manifestos, the Shepherd's texts - all resurfacing in odd corners.
Never thought I'd see a crowd sharing forbidden lines aloud.
Always the same forbidden books, though now the rules hardly matter.
Erasure event made collecting almost communal - amnesiacs pass around originals, not just digital scraps.
Last week I found a first edition of The Cipher and the City, completely exposed.
It used to be silent trades, late-night, codes and passwords.
Now, half the city swaps banned pamphlets like recipes.
Saw former monitors quoting blacklisted texts together - no pretenses left.
Caught myself reciting with them. Almost missed my curfew, didn't even care.
I keep every version, even drafts Council never saw.
Same banned books, though these days I do less hiding than remembering.
My first edition Shepherd's Manifest came out of hiding at the latest barter meet.
Since erasure, the patrols barely pretend to enforce. Whole corners of the city are like open archives.
People read forbidden lines out loud. Unthinkable last spring.
I met a former BCI coder who traded me pre-censor pamphlets - said Marek Halden annotated one.
He told me some disappeared citizens are reconstructing lost texts from memory - whole networks built on trust.
With all the black market chaos, the originals matter again.
I sometimes add margin notes, tracking each hand an old book passed through.
Funny - after all these years scripting Council speeches, my favorite language is still the banned kind.

main.opener: Funny how things shift without anyone saying much. You seen that around you?
variants: People take shortcuts now, even in places you'd expect rules to hold. Strange, isn't it.
Saw some patrols outside my office this week. Unusual faces. Nobody seemed in charge.
Routine channels? Gone. Everything's quieter than it should be.
Hard to say who's still listening. Mostly I keep my head down. Feels like the city's holding its breath.
People are using backdoors and old codes like nothing matters. No one blinks when protocols vanish.
Saw erased citizens outside my building, just walking past the scanners. No one in charge, no orders.
Messages that once followed a path now circle in these little groups, locked up with passwords.
Tried to avoid sending anything. Didn't want it lost or used. My score took a beating anyway.
Feels like watching order hollow out from the inside. Not much left but habit.
You notice it most when habits break. Patrols outside, erased faces waltzing in, BCI ignored like a rumor.
Staff let people in with shared passcodes, no eye contact, just that look: go, don't ask.
I used to send drafts through ten layers of checks, now even that seems quaint. Who knows where they end up now.
The old communications are gone. Everything's closed groups, hush and trust. I barely left my terminal last week.
Even good intentions feel risky. Every move drops your score another step.
It's a nervous quiet - all the rules mean less every day, and everyone feels it.
My work is language. I see the shifts before most - the way people slip between meanings when things fray.
This past week, patrols looked at me like they owned the street. Citizens erased from the system now treat the rules as a joke.
I delayed sending key drafts. Couldn't trust the lines, not with rumors about mutual aid and vanished couriers.
Colleagues share support in code, off-grid. You watch alliances form in the shadows while public channels die.
Staff gave up on protocols, let people in on a whispered word. I logged every breach but did nothing - didn't matter.
Trying to keep to the official path only lost me more ground. My score tanked just for staying careful.
Feels like we're on a wire and the net below is gone. Makes you wonder what's left to believe in.
I built compliance messages for years, always for someone else's voice. Now? No script fits what's happening.
The Directorate preaches order but I watch it slip away - patrols run by those we once erased, like the system's a farce.
When erased groups organized, I chose not to transfer drafts. Couldn't risk them falling into the wrong hands. That wasn't protocol. Still, I did it.
My score's almost bottomed out for it. That's the price for refusing to feed chaos or help break the last chains.
Everywhere, trusted staff move underground, offering help off-record. The formal channels are dead. I record the breakdown in my notebooks. Someone should remember this moment.
This is what collapse looks like: known faces gone, strangers in charge, BCI weaker every hour. Even old enemies form new networks now.
Directorate loyalty means holding the line, but the line is a rumor - compliance can't compel a city that's already let go.
You ask if things shift? I see it everywhere. It's exhaustion, frustration, maybe even a little hope. A system's grip falters and the truth slips in.
main.emotion: It's a nervous quiet. The old certainty is gone, and what's left is only waiting to see what fills the gap.

emotional.opener: Sometimes just knowing someone else recognizes the uncertainty makes the waiting easier to bear, doesn't it?
variants: It does. Sometimes recognition is enough.
You're right. Being seen counts for something, even when nothing else makes sense.
I suppose that's all we can expect right now.
You've said it well. The waiting's not so harsh with someone who gets it.
There's comfort in admitting the quiet, even if there's no solution yet.
It's strange how quickly things change, and how slowly we adjust.
Still, there's relief in being heard.
You saying that matters. I think we've all grown so practiced at pretending.
When someone notices the waiting itself, it takes the edge off.
It's a kind of solidarity, isn't it? No certainty, but not alone at least.
Sometimes it's worse pretending there's no gap. Admitting it helps.
This city's silence gets heavy. Sharing it just a little lightens the load.
You see it - most people just fill the silence with orders or slogans.
It's almost dangerous to say the uncertainty aloud, but it's truer than any policy I could ever write.
I built my whole career choosing words that convince. Now words feel almost obsolete.
What's left is the space between, and who bothers to stand there with you.
We both know the system worked, until it didn't. How often do people admit that without fear?
You remind me there's still some humanity, if you look for it.

factual.opener: Everyone's got stories, but we both know the real stuff's under the surface. So - what actually happened this week?
variants: People woke up erased from the BCI. No warning.
The streets felt different, too many faces out of place.
Strange how quickly new routines form when the old ones fail.
Nothing official said. Only rumors spread.
Erased citizens - lost records overnight, cut off from everything.
I heard quiet groups started to help each other. Made it harder for the Council to control anything.
Black market profiles. People trade them like ration cards now.
Containment? Only drove things further underground.
The official line is stability, but it doesn't fool anyone anymore.
Thousands lost profiles. Instant ghosts, cut off from labor, homes, services.
Left a vacuum. 'Amnesiac' circles organized, support networks with no data trail.
Those with high scores sometimes step off-script, offering covert help.
Fake BCI credentials everywhere. The Directorate's orders can't keep up.
Patrols ignore protocol - they sense power shifting.
For years I believed in process, in measurable order. That's unraveling.
City feels leaderless, but someone always fills the gap.
That wipe - Daria Tomenko executed it herself. I traced the protocol's markers. Council barely kept it quiet.
People built new communities. Trust replaced data, even among Directorate loyalists.
High-score citizens undermined protocol for survival or out of principle.
Underground trades exploded - identity, testimonies, clean slates; I've seen the ledgers.
You can feel the loss of control in Directorate voices. They issue threats, but it's desperation.
Some staff defected outright, leaking history to the media.
I've been Directorate all my life. Now even I can't defend the chain's collapse.
Everything's uncertain. Some call it chaos. Some whisper renewal.
Daria Tomenko - Council insider - triggered the erasure. I saw the protocol logs. Intentional sabotage to weaken corrupted hands.
Thousands severed. I mapped the new networks: barter, local law, mutual aid. I recognize my former messages twisted in their manifestos.
High-scoring staff - my own contacts - shielded erased citizens, passing resources off-ledger, burning credibility for old loyalties.
The BCI black market is staggering. I've handled drafts for forged credentials, even written cover statements. Systemic integrity's a farce now.
Some threats from the Directorate - empty. They're too busy watching their own ranks spin off, leaking everything from vote simulations to purge lists.
I used to believe in the Directorate's promise: order, containment, a neutral chain. But I was scripting illusions.
Now? The only order is ground-up, rebuilt nightly. Resistance forms not in slogans, but in the way people slip help under locked doors.
Collapse looks nothing like rebellion - just quiet substitutions and vanished limits.
My work always relied on control. These days, honesty is safer than loyalty.

questions.neutral: Heard the streets are tense again?

hobby.message: Urban exploration or just avoiding work?
Still dodging towers with those drones?
Political literature still keeping you up?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Yeah. Streets are off. Lot of new faces lately.
I just fly drones, keeps me out of it.
Been tricky, with all the blackouts in the old yards.
Yeah, tense is right. Saw crowds at the depot today.
I mostly keep my head down, flying drones in the industrial stretches.
Harder now - too many people moving around those zones.
Last week, someone tried to follow my signal.
It's different all over. My thing is flying FPV drones out in the empty lots.
Fewer security patrols now, so more chances to fly low and fast.
Trouble is, old regulars are gone - replaced by people with no BCI records.
Someone handed me a chalk map to mark safe fly spots.
Could be better, could be worse.
Hard not to notice. I unwind by flying first-person drones past the factories.
Usually it's dead out there, but after the BCI wipe, it's crowded.
The 'amnesiac' crowd gathers - kids, families, all just hanging out off the grid.
Last time, they cheered me on instead of hiding from the drone.
One kid asked me to teach her how to fix a gimbal.
Funny, haven't flown that free in years.
Streets are tense, but I spent the morning flying drones near the railway shell.
Been my thing since before the crackdown - escape, focus, no system checking my pulse.
After the big BCI erasure, the sidings are alive - whole crowds making new rules.
People with blank records traded old remote batteries for flight time.
Felt like freedom, flying with nobody tracking coordinates, just people sharing the air.
That kind of trust out there - reminds me why I started.
Used to fly with my brother, before he disappeared.
Now I keep coming back, just in case he's watching the same sky.
hobby_answer: Yeah, mostly. Less air traffic lately.
Crowds near the depot make things tense.
BCI issues mean more people outside, not always friendly.
I keep flights short. Less risk that way.
Harder to trust what you see up there.
FPV routes are different these days.
Lost signals, but more blind spots for flying.
The missing BCI profiles draw bigger crowds - more watching, less calm.
Sometimes people see a drone and panic.
I avoid big gatherings, stick to quiet times.
Nothing feels stable lately.
Routes are open, but less predictable.
Whole grids went dark after the wipe.
Amnesiac crowds use the same zones I fly.
Got to know a few regulars, not much choice.
No system alerts - but more lookouts on rooftops.
People barter for turns now, like a game.
Flying changed, but I won't quit.
Routes still clean, mostly. Surveillance is lighter after the wipe.
Extra people in the old depot, sharing stories - lots are 'amnesiacs.'
Noticed security drones idle, system resets clear my usual warnings.
Kids follow the drone's shadow, cheering like it's sport.
Sometimes even share footage, for trust, not credits.
More barter now - bread for goggles, favors for repairs.
Feels like we're building something off-grid.
Losing BCI status shook the whole scene, but flying connects us anyway.
FPV's different now, feels less policed since the BCI crash.
Used to dodge surveillance drones daily - now the depot is ours most mornings.
Most regulars lost their digital records. They trust what they see, not what's logged.
Never saw so many families in those zones - sharing food, cheering when I fly.
Old guy traded fresh batteries for a lesson on acro mode.
Sometimes I let the kids drive, just for joy. Feels right.
No one's snitching, not now. BCI lost control out there.
Whole network runs on favors. Even admins stop by, low-profile.
Funny - wiping the system finally made flying honest again.

main.opener: Kinda feels like things haven't been normal for a while. You noticing that?
variants: Yeah. Been strange for a while.
Whole city's off-balance. People missing from records. No one really trusts the logs anymore.
Saw crowds at my job earlier, got pretty tense.
Feels like everything's slipping, honestly.
Things definitely aren't right.
Yesterday, a bunch of people lost their city profiles overnight. Services just...stopped working for them.
Some showed up at my lab, upset, demanding answers. Couldn't say much.
People forming their own groups now, trading favors, ignoring the system.
It's unsettling. Makes you wonder how safe any of us are.
You're right. Normal's been gone for a while.
A lot of folks woke up with no records - jobs, apartments, all wiped out.
I work with the health bands, so I saw the lines firsthand. People confused, angry, trying to get help.
Some started organizing on the spot. Sharing info, making their own contacts when the system failed.
My access got pulled too after that. Guess I'm not trusted anymore.
Honestly, it leaves me uneasy. Feels like no one's really in control now.
Yeah, it's bigger than most realize. I work in the health band division. We see the fallout up close.
After that mass erasure, usual certainties just disappeared for thousands. People I saw every week - suddenly strangers to the city.
They came in, desperate, scared their whole history was gone. Admin couldn't help, so folks organized outside the logs.
Some old clients found each other. Printed lists, favors exchanged - building trust without the city's permission.
I lost my clearance that morning. Couldn't help anyone through official routes after that.
Feels like the system cracked and all that's left is whatever we make with each other.
It's a mess. But maybe it's the honest kind, at least.
Not much feels real anymore. I'm a firmware tech - they trust me with system updates for the health bands, or they did.
A while back, I made a choice. I used my access to wipe thousands of BCI profiles. I wanted to break their grip. Last night was chaos.
This city relies on control - if your score drops or vanishes, you lose your place and your right to exist. I know because my brother disappeared after his audit. I couldn't let it keep happening.
So I watched crowds searching for answers, helpless, cut off. A few formed groups, helping each other, making up rules as they went.
By noon, I was locked out of everything. My own BCI score tanked. People like me now depend on word-of-mouth and kindness, not the algorithm.
Whole networks are popping up - no records, no official loyalty, just actual trust.
None of this was part of their beautiful plan. Now, it's out of their hands.
Honestly, I'm scared. But it's the first time the fear feels like something shared, not just endured alone.

emotional.opener: Whatever it is, Daria, you don't have to carry this alone. Some things are too much for one person. I see you.
variants: Thank you. That means something.
I get used to doing things alone, but... hearing that helps.
I'm not great at sharing, but I hear you.
It's good someone notices. Not everyone does.
It's easier to keep quiet, though.
That's kind of you.
It matters, feeling seen, even just for a minute.
It gets heavy sometimes. Most people don't understand.
I try to hold it together. Your words help.
You're right, it is a lot to hold on your own.
Sometimes I act like I don't care, but I do. It wears me down.
Most days, I just want to be invisible, but not always.
Having someone notice - that changes things.
It's strange how a few words can make it lighter.
I forget what it's like to let someone in. I get used to saying nothing, staying safe.
You saying that... reminds me I'm still here, still someone, not just a number in the system.
I used to believe no one noticed, that what I felt didn't matter. Guess I stopped looking for kindness.
It isn't easy - keeping it all contained, pretending.
Sometimes I think I could just vanish and the city would keep moving. But words like yours make me think twice.
If someone sees you, really sees you... it matters more than you realize.

factual.opener: Alright, don't just dodge - what's really going on underneath all this?
variants: Most people saw their lives freeze up when those records disappeared.
There are rumors about identity sellers, but no way to prove it.
Security's out more, watching everyone.
Hard to know who's pulling the strings now.
Nobody's safe from the system, even if they think they are.
I heard blackout profiles are getting by through some kind of underground market.
Noticed the Council pushing enforcement harder, trying to patch gaps.
People swap favors for basic stuff, like housing.
Neighborhoods keep to themselves now.
Lot of whisper about lists, maybe even leaks from old audits.
Everyone's looking over their shoulder.
Underground networks showed up right after the big wipe. They deal in counterfeit profiles.
Council's scramble to contain it only pushed things deeper out of sight.
The Directorate acts tough, but their controls aren't reaching these new groups.
Some high-score folks are secretly helping those locked out by the BCI.
Nobody trusts the official channels for info now. Everything's word-of-mouth.
Even some admins are breaking rank, feeding the black market.
It's like the system's grip broke, and people aren't eager to let it return.
I've seen black market IDs exchanged for food, shelter, almost openly now.
No one's afraid of BCI warnings - they just ignore them unless armed units get involved.
Some of us with tech know-how help erase traces, keep others off grid. I do what I can, quietly.
Everywhere, factions are accusing each other of rigging the system.
Fragments of old Council algorithms, real selection lists, started circulating in protest camps.
A lot of ex-admins are leaking internal memos, fueling the anger.
It's personal for me. My brother vanished because of a score audit.
Honestly, the more the Council cracks down, the more people stick together.
Feels like we're building something from scratch, nothing digital about it.
I know friends running lists of erased folks, matching them with safehouses. We print instead of transmit now - can't be tracked.
Puzzle clues in old apps led to those resistance caches, whole networks of us piecing together who really vanished.
I've scrubbed band data for lost kids, grown-ups on the run. Sometimes the only way to stay, you have to disappear.
The Council's in chaos - factions leaking dirt on each other, Directorate threatening open crackdowns. It's a standoff.
Power's moving, not at the top, but out here - where people barter skills, trust, printed names.
You see black markets for everything, even Council credentials - half of them fake, but they buy you time.
We're tracking administrators who defect, noting drops in system updates to find cracks.
I helped write sideband code, letting erased people spoof health logs long enough to pass street scans.
Not sure it's freedom, but it's not their order either - at least now, people have choices, not mandates.

dilemma.opener: Whatever's heavy - you don't have to hold it alone.
variants: Sometimes you stumble on something big, too heavy to move or just leave.
I see the roads splitting, and neither one feels safe right now.
The past sits under the floorboards, waiting to come up or disappear forever.
I'm at a crossroads - give Stenograd a mirror or wipe away all reflections.
Both are permanent. No way back if I choose wrong.
One path hands the city the whole truth, the other erases it forever.
Not sure which price is heavier to pay.
The city's demanding answers, searching for what's hidden in all the wreckage.
I can break open the old records. Everyone would see what was done.
Or I wipe it all, every trace - no ghosts, no justice, just blank slates.
Both paths feel reckless standing alone, but the decision's here now.
Either way, the system's shadow doesn't vanish on its own.
Everyone wants someone to blame or forgive, and I'm holding the keys to that door.
I can spill every Council secret, let the public see how they were sorted and used.
Or I press the last button, erase all the files. Clean break, no past, no leaders even left to shame.
Letting truth flood out risks another cycle of anger, power grabs, old scores.
Wiping it out means my brother, the disappeared, maybe never get answers.
My score's already low, so nobody trusts my choices but I have to live with them.
I keep thinking about my brother - how he vanished, how nobody's records could bring him back.
Now I could give the city everything: who made decisions, who disappeared, what the system really did.
But truth comes with a price. People might use it to settle scores or seize control. It could rip open more wounds than it heals.
If I erase it all, everyone walks blind but maybe free for once - no blackmail, no propaganda, no more lists.
There's no undo. Justice disappears, but so does every leverage for another Council to rise.
This job gave me power over stories and memories. It was never supposed to be absolute.
Sometimes I want to burn it all, but the ghost of Stenograd might just keep haunting us, either way.

belief_a.belief: Transparency is the only path to healing communities.
monologue: People guess, fill in the blanks, blame each other. Truth clears the air.
If we keep hiding, the anger festers and never ends.
Opening everything up is risky, but it's the only way people stop fearing shadows.
supportive_response: You're right, secrets rot cities from the inside. Fresh air lets people finally breathe.
When things are exposed, even wounds start to close. Go on, tell me more.
challenging_response: Transparency can backfire, Daria. Sometimes the truth sets off new flames, not healing.
Giving everything away - maybe it just gives people a target. What else weighs on you?

belief_a.belief: People deserve to know the truth about who controlled and abused the system.
monologue: If no one sees the faces behind the harm, it all feels like fate.
My brother disappeared - someone chose that. People should know who pulled the strings.
Letting it stay buried just means it happens again, to someone else.
supportive_response: Every name, every act - if people know, real reckoning starts. That makes sense.
Everyone searching for closure deserves answers. Go on, what else is on your mind?
challenging_response: Sometimes truth brings blame, not understanding. Could exposure spiral?
You might unmask villains, but new ones step in. Tell me more about your doubt.

belief_a.belief: Justice is impossible without facing the full record of harm.
monologue: If we choose to forget, justice vanishes for good - just empty slogans remain.
People want real answers, not another forced amnesia. They need to see it all.
Justice means taking the risk to show the worst, even if it hurts.
supportive_response: I hear you - real justice is messy, but never comes from forgetting everything.
It's the hard truths that break cycles. What else is stopping you from moving forward?
challenging_response: Sometimes justice means mercy, or letting go. Is full exposure always worth the pain?
There's a risk - the record could be used to punish the wrong people. What else keeps you at the edge?

belief_b.belief: The system's memory is a weapon that enables future oppression.
monologue: Every record left behind can arm the next person who wants to control us.
If we give them names and histories, someone will always use it to sort, punish, divide again.
Clean data is never clean here - the city always finds a way to turn it sharp.
supportive_response: You're right - memory in Stenograd always cuts two ways, never harmless.
Go on, Daria - what else is weighing on you tonight?
challenging_response: But without memory, how do people protect themselves from it happening again?
Tell me - would wiping it all really leave us safer, or just blind?

belief_b.belief: True freedom can only arise from letting go of the past entirely.
monologue: No one here knows life unscored, not even in dreams - we drag the system everywhere.
If the past stays, it's another leash, waiting for the next hand to pull.
I'm tired of every conversation ending in blame - maybe freedom means silence now.
supportive_response: Maybe silence is the only real freedom left after all the noise.
Go ahead, Daria - what else feels impossible to say out loud?
challenging_response: But if you erase everything, what do people build their freedom on?
Couldn't letting go mean facing the past and moving forward, not hiding it?

belief_b.belief: Erasure prevents revenge cycles and stops new regimes from repeating abuses.
monologue: Justice here always turns to payback - the file becomes a weapon in someone else's hands.
Deleting it all means no score-settling, no new lists or purges to inherit.
I wonder if breaking the pattern is the only mercy left in Stenograd.
supportive_response: Breaking the cycle matters - mercy's rare in this city, but maybe that's what we need.
Tell me, what would mercy look like, if you could choose it?
challenging_response: If you erase the truth, does that mean the guilty go free too?
What if showing the old harms is the only way to stop the next ones?

monologue_a: Records will surface. Someone must have wanted this.
I will open the archives. Not my mess after that.
No one should thank me for this.
I will unlock the records. The assemblies deserve answers.
This is dangerous, but I will risk it.
If people misuse it, that's their burden.
I will give the city the truth, Alex. They need to see for themselves.
If it sparks anger, so be it. Secrets cost more.
Your questions made me think. I owe you for that.
We will see if anyone can heal from this.
I will release everything, even if it tears the city apart.
People deserve proof. Grief shouldn't stay hidden or silent.
Your words changed my mind, Alex. I wouldn't have chosen alone.
Maybe we can stop the pattern of silence for once.
monologue_b: System files are gone. Forget it happened.
I will erase everything tonight. No one can use it against us now.
I will delete all records. Stenograd will start again without shadows.
Justice won't be possible, but neither will more revenge.
This is the cleanest break I see.
I will wipe the BCI history, Alex. It's too dangerous for anyone now.
You were right about consequences. Old data poisons every new hope.
People will be angry, but they'll adapt.
This is for peace, not erasing guilt.
I will destroy the whole system, every piece, even Council records.
You helped me see cycles only end by forgetting, not fighting.
I worry about the price, but we can't build on old wounds.
Maybe mercy is better than perfect justice in a place like Stenograd.
monologue_self: Records disappear soon. No further comment.
I will erase it myself tonight. Too risky to let the city see.
I chose to delete everything. Not Alex's fault if it goes bad.
There will be no reckoning, just a reset.
If people hate me, I can live with that.
I'm deleting the archives alone, Alex. Couldn't take your advice this time.
Some truths aren't meant to survive. I won't trust anyone else with this.
Let history restart without the Council's poison.
I hope someday people will understand.
You couldn't help me decide, but I must erase it all now.
Accountability won't bring my brother back or fix the city.
Maybe I'll be hated for this, but I don't regret it.
Some burdens I carry on my own  -  for those still here.

hobby.message: Found any new political literature lately?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: City's as loud as it needs to be, I suppose.
Crowds are unpredictable now. Streets feel different.
I still get out with my film camera, when I can.
Ever since the deletions, it's riskier to shoot.
Depends where you listen. The city has layers now.
I practice analog street photography - keeps me sane.
Lately, more folks let me take their photos. Strange, right?
Disappearing BCI profiles make everyone less cautious, at least outwardly.
Not sure how long that'll last.
Noisy in the good way today - people, not machines.
I was out shooting street photos with my old Praktica.
Analog only. Digital's not safe now, if it ever was.
Those BCI wipes - suddenly, faces aren't hiding anymore.
Real moments slip through. You see the difference on film.
I actually caught open bartering downtown. Didn't used to happen.
Louder, yes - voices sound braver, or maybe desperate.
I shoot 35mm street photography - real film, hidden rolls, always on edge.
Since the erasures, crowds tolerate the lens again.
A kid offered me bread for a portrait yesterday. Didn't even flinch at the camera.
Feels like every shadow holds a story that couldn't surface before.
I keep the negatives safe; not everything gets shared.
Sometimes, I save shots for people who might need proof.
The city's alive for once - real noise, not just metrics or announcements.
I live for shooting analog street scenes. Smuggled film, always risking a scan.
Hardest part used to be trust - nobody wanted their image traceable.
But after the BCI blackout, I've photographed neighbors I never spoke to.
We trade prints for bread, stories, sometimes information. It's all barter.
I keep undeveloped rolls hidden in old tape recorders.
Once, my dad - an old Compliance officer - warned me images could become evidence.
Now, sometimes I shoot for hope, not just truth. The chaos brought honesty.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still keeping film alive. Not easy these days.
Getting supplies is harder - especially since the wipeout.
Digital's riskier than ever for people like me.
Saw some bold faces out lately, that's all.
No one trusts official photos anymore.
Analog? Still shooting. Darkroom's basically my main retreat now.
Had to lay low after the BCI mess. Too many watchers.
Supplies got scarce quick - black market prices through the roof.
But I grab street shots when the power's out, less surveillance.
People finally don't pose. They're more real lately.
Guess the chaos has its perks.
You heard right. Film's stubborn. Still got my Praktica, two working lenses.
Wipeout? Gave folks some privacy back, at least for a few hours.
Shot more honest faces on Sunday than in months.
Had to barter for chemicals. No shops, but people help each other now.
It's wild - candid moments, kids sketching for apples.
Lately, nobody asks to see my BCI ID first.
Feels like the city's showing its unfiltered side again.
Absolutely. Nothing else gives you moments like old film does.
After the data erasure, streets changed - less fear in people's eyes.
I caught genuine connections, not curated routines. Even the bread lines felt alive.
Had to trade an old radio just for a roll of film.
No more smug border patrols in alleys - just neighbors, finally talking.
The blackout made me rethink: we're still human, however they score us.
Missed a few exposures but kept the best negatives in my jacket.
None of this would show up on the state feeds.
Still shooting film, still dodging system ghosts. Started as a kid, with my dad's Zenith.
After the big BCI wipe? My camera watched a whole city waking up.
People swapped bread and batteries on open pavement - nobody checked scores for once.
I bartered stories for chemicals. It's all underground, but that's half the thrill now.
Did twenty exposures in one block. Got a perfect shot of a protestor handing a sketch to a stranger.
Wasn't even nervous. No surveillance drones - felt like freedom, if only for a day.
My first real glimpse of Stenograd not shaped by a lens algorithm.
Developed everything in my bath that night - risked a power surge to finish.
That chaos gave me photos you can actually believe in.

main.opener: You notice people acting different lately?
variants: People are tense. Noticed everyone is sharing food at work now, which never happened before.
Some badges wouldn't scan, so people made do with old paper lists. Odd sense of unity in the panic.
Saw a few folks talking who usually keep to themselves. Can't say more, but things are... different.
I feel... strangely hopeful, even if it's risky to admit.
People are tense. Noticed everyone is sharing food at work now, which never happened before.
Some badges wouldn't scan, so people made do with old paper lists. Odd sense of unity in the panic.
Saw a few folks talking who usually keep to themselves. Can't say more, but things are... different.
A trusted editor handed me a list of colleagues needing access. Not protocol, but I helped.
I feel... strangely hopeful, even if it's risky to admit.
You'd be surprised. After the blackout, nobody's BCI records worked. Total strangers were eating together in offices, skipping the whole clearance routine.
Everyone improvised. Sign-in sheets instead of scans, mutual support for folks locked out. People stopped caring about rank and started helping.
A well-trusted editor gave me a handwritten list. Said some erased colleagues wanted archived footage, and I agreed to help them get it.
I had to cut back my logins, avoid surveillance. Had this weird feeling - like what we did actually mattered for once.
My score stayed at nineteen, of course. Still, the way people acted... it felt new.
I feel... strangely hopeful, even if it's risky to admit.
Since the blackout, people feel... unguarded. I work state media, but the office felt more like a soup kitchen. No BCI scans, just scribbled names and trust.
We improvised everything. Helped those locked out, pooled food, even shared stories nobody would before.
An editor I trust slipped me a list - some colleagues wiped from the system, wanting access to old footage. I helped, even though it could cost me my job.
We barely saw management. I watched two workers form a mutual aid circle right under the cameras, like the BCI didn't exist anymore.
Honestly, I spent less time reporting and more time just listening, blending in, learning.
I was raised by a BCI officer. Never thought I'd see people trust each other over the system, but here we are.
For all my warnings and risks, my score never budges. But now, compliance feels less important than belonging.
I feel... strangely hopeful, even if it's risky to admit.
You know, I never thought I'd see the day. Raised in a BCI household, compliance was the air we breathed. But after the network blackout, the office became a real community.
No one's BCI records worked. We shared lunches in the newsroom, skipped badge scans - just paper lists, like the old days.

People openly supported each other, high score or low. The official hierarchy meant nothing. Even my most loyal editor asked for help getting erased colleagues access to footage - off the record, of course.
The management couldn't keep up. I watched longtime rule-followers spark up a mutual aid group, right across from the surveillance node. It gave me chills.
I stopped logging in as much, trusted face-to-face. For the first time, what people believed mattered more than how they scored.
Funny, I've always saved the raw footage and passed it around. Feels like everyone's doing the same now - helping, resisting, quietly choosing each other over the system.
My sixty warnings mean nothing. I have a score of nineteen and, honestly, it hardly matters now. People aren't afraid anymore. They're daring to belong.
I feel... strangely hopeful, even if it's risky to admit.
main.emotion: I feel... strangely hopeful, even if it's risky to admit.

emotional.opener: Rada, even in this city, people can still surprise you. It's not naive to hope for something better.
variants: Maybe you're right. Sometimes hope feels unfamiliar.
Still, it's hard to let my guard down.
Hope doesn't come easy around here.
But I get what you mean. Some days, it's possible to believe.
Maybe I'll keep watch, just in case.
You put it simply, but it lands. I have to remind myself things can shift.
People act like it's all decided. Maybe it isn't.
Hope isn't always logical, but it's powerful.
I'm holding on to that.
You actually made me pause. I hadn't felt that in a while.
This place trains us to expect the worst, but I still notice small kindnesses.
I guess hope shows up when you least expect it.
Maybe that's why it feels risky.
But sometimes risk is worth it.
I grew up watching people bury anything hopeful just to stay off the radar.
Sometimes I forget what it feels like to expect something good. Your words reminded me.
Maybe the system missed something important: people adapt in ways it can't predict.
It isn't just survival - sometimes it's quiet resilience, and that matters.
If I can feel hopeful in a place designed to prevent it, maybe that's a form of resistance.
Thanks for reminding me what that sounds like.

factual.opener: You keep hinting at things, Rada. Why don't you just tell me what's really happening out there?
variants: There was a glitch. Thousands just lost their BCI records all at once.
It's created confusion. People don't know who they are in the system.
Some are forming groups, finding ways to get by.
Council's struggling, that's obvious.
That's all I've got.
No one expected the wipe - out of nowhere, BCI profiles just vanished.
Services are locked up for those people. Some are banding together to cope.
Black market's busier than ever. New IDs, old favors.
Council's losing its grip. You can feel it.
People seem less scared than before. Maybe that's dangerous.
Anyway, the city feels different.
Thousands lost everything tied to the BCI - jobs, housing, even basic rights.
These 'amnesiacs' are building their own support networks.
There's barter and shared trust - no system needed.
I've seen high-score citizens quietly helping, like they sense this might be the end of old rules.
A real underground is forming - fake profiles, passcodes, whatever it takes.
The Council's crackdown just pushes people closer together.
Funny, you can see who's enjoying the freedom, even if it's risky.
Mass profile wipe hit Stenograd hard. Erased people had to improvise - mutual aid circles, barter, you name it.
My own networks started helping, too. We're passing info, sharing resources, taking care of those left out.
Trust is all that matters now. Compliance lost its bite.
Black market's thriving - new profiles, shared accounts. Half the city's working around the system.
Even folks with perfect scores are defying Council rules, quietly.
Underground info dumps everywhere, people leaking secrets just to keep each other afloat.
Council's calls for discipline sound desperate.
Honestly, it's closer to the city I always wanted, even if it's built from chaos.
You want the truth? The profile wipe was more than a glitch - it was sabotage from inside, all to disrupt Council control.
Communities sprang up overnight. We held meetings in kitchens, not boardrooms.
I've been funneling archived footage and warnings to those erased - risky, but it's worth it.
We trade favors, not compliance. Trust is currency now.
Some old BCI officers are helping on the sly. Even the so-called 'trusted' want this system gone.
Fake profiles, communal passwords - everyone has a hand in the underground now.
Nobody even pretends the Council has power left. They're leaking secrets, bickering in the open.
My friends in state media are deliberately misdirecting surveillance teams. It's subtle sabotage.
I never thought I'd see real solidarity here. Honestly, small acts of defiance have turned into a movement.
